content.text: A universal word like “hi” might seem simple, perhaps even insignificant. However, around the globe, this short greeting carries profound power to connect people, build friendships, and foster a sense of community. From bustling urban centers to quiet rural villages, saying “hi” has become the basis for establishing trust, understanding, and meaningful dialogue.

The Harmony Greeting Campaign is an initiative that seeks to highlight the importance of simple communication in an increasingly disconnected world. Children, teenagers, and even adults, from countries such as India, Germany, Japan, Mexico, Kenya, the United States, and Brazil, are taking part by creatively exploring the cultural nuances of greetings. Participants craft “hi banners” using recycled materials as a way of saying hello and promoting unity in their communities.

Last month, hundreds of “hi banners” found their way to a community hub in Oregon, USA—a cozy café-slash-workshop called Greeting Grounds. This space serves as a focal spot for conversation and collaboration.

Greeting Grounds is a family-run establishment managed by longtime social advocates, Andy and Sarah Holden. It specializes in providing equal parts coffee and creativity. Hailing from a family of artists, Andy and Sarah dreamed of offering a venue for people to gather and express their ideas through art and discussion. Today, Greeting Grounds is regarded as a center for social engagement and collective action.

Sarah Holden first discovered the Harmony Greeting Campaign through a local newspaper. She was captivated by the simplicity of its mission: bring people closer through an everyday expression. As an artist with a deep appreciation for the handmade, Sarah felt inspired to contribute.

“Greetings are such an integral part of human connection, and it's not about the language or the length of the word but the intention behind it,” she explains. “I loved how the campaign emphasized using recycled materials for the banners—it's eco-friendly and deeply symbolic, showing how little things can mean a lot in creating unity.”

Sarah learned from the article that Harmony's spokeswoman, Louisa Tran, was actively rallying volunteers to sew and piece together banners. “We're inviting everyone—teachers, students, families—to say 'hi' creatively and to promote harmony, not just among people but also with the planet,” Tran had said.

Moved by this idea, Sarah made calls to her friends and fellow regulars at the café, offering the space as a free venue for stitching together the banners. Andy joined in by sending emails to local organizations and schools, inviting the community to come and contribute time or resources. Within weeks, dozens of responses poured in.

Louisa Tran expressed her gratitude for these efforts. “We're operating on a modest budget,” she said. “Initiatives like this thrive on the goodwill and generosity of people.” Andy was equally amazed. “Even people who've never sewn before came forward just to help stitch banners and exchange ideas,” he recalled.

One teacher, Mrs. Lena Frost, saw the impact of the campaign firsthand in her classroom. After receiving Andy's email, she encouraged her second-grade class to design their banner patches and think critically about what a simple “hi” could communicate. Seven-year-old Ruby chose bright pink fabric for her patch. “When I say hi, I want it to feel like sunshine,” she explained.
Meanwhile, her classmate Ethan focused on kindness. “I'm writing my hi with a picture of hands shaking,” he said proudly. “It's like saying, 'Let's be friends.'”

Twelve-year-old Victor from a neighboring middle school took part too. He worked on bold, block letters using old shirts. “When I say hi, I mean, 'Let's connect and learn.' I think we should always try to understand one another—even if we don't speak the same language.”

The campaign also encouraged families to join. Marina Walsh brought her four children to Greeting Grounds for banner-making day. “It's important for kids to see how small gestures can lead to bigger changes,” she reflected. Her youngest, Oliver, enjoyed using glitter and stickers to personalize his patch. “I added stars so my hi feels special,” he chimed in cheerfully.

Others contributed more abstract designs. Phyllis Monroe, an elderly participant from the area, described her creation: “I embroidered the word 'hi' surrounded by a swirl of colors. It's like how a greeting opens new doors to different emotions, ideas, or friendships.”

Louisa Tran explained that the Harmony Greeting Campaign is just the start of a global movement to foster connection. “Children, teenagers, and adults alike are rediscovering the impact of something so fundamental as saying hi,” she said during an interview. “Through this campaign, we hope to build confidence in communication, empathy, and community action—and to show that everyone has a role in bridging divides.”

The Harmony Greeting Campaign is also gearing up for new activities that extend its original mission. Louisa teased about upcoming projects. “Our second campaign will focus on encouraging kids to write letters to strangers expressing kindness and support. The third one might revolve around organizing neighborhood meet-and-greet days.”

The completed banners, over 1,000 in total, were showcased in Portland and Seattle for World Friendship Day last month. They will tour other major cities over the coming year. To continue encouraging human connection, Harmony is offering a digital platform where participants can design virtual greeting banners and share them across the world.
In a world that sometimes feels fractured, a simple “hi” carries the potential to inspire hope, spark change, and create a shared sense of identity beyond borders.
